Shetland Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Chalk facie of chalky limestones, limestones, marls, and calcareous shales and mudstones.  Chert occurs throughout the facies.  The siliciclastic facies consists of mudstones and shales, partly interbedded with limestones. (Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STLN">STLN</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl	Sullom Fm.	65.50	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous claystone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SULM">SULM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Danian. REFERENCE = Knox et al. 1997. Stratigraphic nomenclature of the UK North West Margin. 2. Early Paleogene lithostratigraphy and sequence stratigraphy. BGS.
	Clayey limestone	Jorsalfare Fm.	75.13	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous claystone.  Mudstones interbedded with thin limestones beds.  The mudstones are light to medium grey, often calcareous.  The limestones are white to light grey, fine grained, occasionally sandy and dolomitic. (Isaksen and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=JRSF">JRSF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Campanian
	Claystone	Kyrre Fm.	89.57	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones with occasional limestone beds.  The mudstones are medium grey to grey ,silty to calcareous, occasionally pyritic, glauconitic or micaceous.  The sandstones are clear to white, and very fine to fine grained. (Isaksen and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KYRE">KYRE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Turonian
Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, with marl seams and flint layers in parts.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Chalk	Herring Fm.	93.55	LITHOLOGY = Chalk with chert  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HERN">HERN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Turonian
	Chalk	Hidra Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Chalk with chert  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HIDR">HIDR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Cenomanian
Cromer Knoll Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine-grained , argillaceous, marine sediments with a varying content of calcareous material.  Calcareous claystones, siltstones and marlstones dominate, but subordinate layers of limestones and sandstone occur.  The claystones are generally light to dark grey, olive-grey, greenish and brownish, often becoming light grey, light greenish grey and light olive-grey marlstones.  Mica, pyrite and glauconite are common.  Generally, marlstones become the more dominant lithology in both the upper and lower parts of the Gp.. (Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRKN">CRKN</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Victory Fm.	142.82	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=VICY">VICY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Middle of Berriasian
Humber Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HMBG">HMBG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	145.46	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous, kerogen-rich, or silty); thin siltstone and cementstone beds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Berriasian
	Sandstone	Rona Fm.	162.98	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RONA">RONA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Average is 50% up in Callovian.  Base of Kimmeridgian in mid-depth areas; and base of Bajocian in most distal.. REFERENCE = Ritchie et al. 1996. Stratigraphic nomenclature of the UK North West Margin. 1. 	Volcanic ash	Balder Fm.	53.64	LITHOLOGY = Volcanic-ash-rich;  Laminated varicoloured, fissile shales with interbeded grey, green and buff, often pyritic, sandy tuffs and occasional stringers of limestone, dolomite and siderite. (Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BALD">BALD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Ypresian
	Claystone	Flett Fm.	54.72	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FLET">FLET</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in Ypresian
	Sandstone	Colsay Sandstone	56.54	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COYS">COYS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = About 75% up in Thanetian
Faroe Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  
	Claystone	Lamba Fm	58.74	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LMBA">LMBA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Thanetian. REFERENCE = Knox et al. 1997. Stratigraphic nomenclature of the UK North West Margin. 2. Early Paleogene lithostratigraphy and sequence stratigraphy. BGS.
	Volcanic ash	Kettla Fm.	59.34	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KTLA">KTLA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = about 80% up in Selandian
	Sandy claystone	Vaila Fm.	63.04	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=VAIL">VAIL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = about 65% up in Danian
Shetland Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Chalk facie of chalky limestones, limestones, marls, and calcareous shales and mudstones.  Chert occurs throughout the facies.  The siliciclastic facies consists of mudstones and shales, partly interbedded with limestones. (Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STLN">STLN</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl	Sullom Fm.	63.80	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous claystone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SULM">SULM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in Danian. REFERENCE = Knox et al. 1997. Stratigraphic nomenclature of the UK North West Margin. 2. Early Paleogene lithostratigraphy and sequence stratigraphy. BGS.
	Sandstone	Ockran Sandstone Fm.	65.50	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=OCKS">OCKS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Danian
	Clayey limestone	Jorsalfare Fm.	75.13	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones interbedded with thin limestones beds.  The mudstones are light to medium grey, often calcareous.  The limestones are white to light grey, fine grained, occasionally sandy and dolomitic. (Isaksen and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=JRSF">JRSF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Campanian
	Claystone	Kyrre Fm.	89.57	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones with occasional limestone beds.  The mudstones are medium grey to grey ,silty to calcareous, occasionally pyritic, glauconitic or micaceous.  The sandstones are clear to white, and very fine to fine grained. (Isaksen and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KYRE">KYRE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Turonian
Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, with marl seams and flint layers in parts.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Chalk	Macbeth Fm.	93.55	LITHOLOGY = Chalk with chert  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MCBT">MCBT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Turonian
	Continental marl	Svarte Fm	95.67	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous claystone (but marine setting).  Mudstones interbedded with limestones. (Isaksen and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SVRT">SVRT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Cenomanian.  Extends to base of Cenomanian seaward (Commodore Fm. pinches out)
Cromer Knoll Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine-grained , argillaceous, marine sediments with a varying content of calcareous material.  Calcareous claystones, siltstones and marlstones dominate, but subordinate layers of limestones and sandstone occur.  The claystones are generally light to dark grey, olive-grey, greenish and brownish, often becoming light grey, light greenish grey and light olive-grey marlstones.  Mica, pyrite and glauconite are common.  Generally, marlstones become the more dominant lithology in both the upper and lower parts of the Gp.. (Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRKN">CRKN</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Commodore Fm	105.80	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COMM">COMM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Approx. 50% up in Albian.  Pinches out toward distal (minimum is at base of Cenomanian)
	Claystone	Cruiser Fm.	112.00	LITHOLOGY = Claystone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRUI">CRUI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Albian.
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Royal Sovereign Fm.	121.10	LITHOLOGY = Coarse-grained sandstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ROSO">ROSO</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Aptian
	Sandstone	Neptune Fm.	125.00	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NEPT">NEPT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Schematically, base of Aptian (actually, it is more distal than Royal Sovereign, and pinches out in proximal.  Proximal is a gap above Kimmeridge Clay, until incoming of Royal Sovereign Fm.  However, included Neptune Fm. here for completeness.
	Gap		142.82	CALIBRATION = Middle of Berriasian
Humber Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HMBG">HMBG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	155.65	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous, kerogen-rich, or silty); thin siltstone and cementstone beds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Kimmeridgian
	Claystone	Heather Fm.	184.65	LITHOLOGY = Very silty claystone with thin streaks of limestone. (Vollset and Dore, 1984).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HTHE">HTHE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 75% up in Pliensbachian.  Base of sedimentation in distal regions.

	TOP		2650.00	CALIBRATION = Mid-NeoArchean

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Appleby Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Red, aeolian cross-bedded millet-seed sandstone, fluviatile sandstone and breccias ('Brockram') interbedded in varying proportions. Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl amd marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base. Purbeck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones, limestones and evaporites of marginal freshwater, brackish and marine origin; detrital quartz occurs in parts. The Gp. (Purbeck Beds), was traditionally divided into Lower, Middle and Upper units ('beds') with a key marker, the Cinder Bed placed within the middle part of the Middle Purbeck Beds. At the type site in Dorset, the Gp. is now formally divided into the Lulworth Fm., below and the Durlston Fm. above with the base of the Durlston Fm. placed at the base of the Cinder Bed. This formal terminology can now be applied throughout the outcrop and subcrop of the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PB">PB</a> ].  
	Siltstone	Hastings Beds	134.76	LITHOLOGY = Base of silts and sands of Ashdown Fm. on soft mudstones of the Upper Purbeck.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HAS">HAS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 25% up in Purbeck Gp.. BGS website claims this Fm. belongs to the Wealden Gp.. 
	Continental marl	Upper Purbeck Beds	135.15	LITHOLOGY = No details.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=UPB">UPB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in Purbeck Gp..
	Clayey limestone	Miiddle Purbeck Beds	136.70	LITHOLOGY = No details.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MPB">MPB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 75% up in Purbeck Gp..

 	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.). Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].

New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. Stromatolites particularly abundant in Durness area.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ELD">ELD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the Paibian.
	Dolomite	Ghrudaidh Fm.	508.25	LITHOLOGY = Dark to mid-grey dolostones containing burrow mottling, oolitic and bioclastic grainstones and rare stromatolites.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=GUD">GUD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at about 50% up in stage 5 of the Cambrian.
Ardvreck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The lowest unit of the Gp. is the Basal Quartzite Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is cross-bedded, fine- to medium-grained, quartz arenite, although locally the base reaches pebble grade. Compositionally, the basal part is also feldspar rich, up to subarkose in places, but the proportion and grain size decreases rapidly upwards. The unit is overlain by cross-bedded quartz arenites of the Pipe Rock Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is a fine- to coarse-grained, quartz arenite with abundant Skolithos burrows at most levels. Localised staining by ferric iron oxide is present in the upper part of the Member, commonly differentially distributed between burrows and matrix. The Eriboll Fm. is conformably overlain by dolomitic siltstones, with minor dolomitic grainstones and dolomitic sandstones, of the Fucoid Beds Member (An t-Sron Fm.).  The Fucoid Beds Member is in turn overlain by the Salterella Grit Member (An t-Sron Fm.) which marks a return to cross-bedded quartz arenites containing Skolithos, but also containing abundant agglutinated shells of Salterella.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ARDV">ARDV</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone	An t-Sron Fm.	512.45	LITHOLOGY = Two distinctive members: dolomitic brown-coloured siltstone, mudstone and sandstone of the Fucoid Beds Member, and white quartz-sandstone of the Salterella Grit Member.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASR">ASR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at 65% up in stage 4 of the Cambrian.
	Sandstone	Eriboll Fm.	534.60	LITHOLOGY = Quartz-sandstone with a thin basal conglomerate.  Lower Basal Quartzite Member and upper Pipe Rock Member containing abundant Skolithos burrows.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ERSA">ERSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of stage 2 of the Cambrian.
 	Primary
	TOP		880.00	CALIBRATION = Drawn 80% up in the Tonian.

New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. Ardvreck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The lowest unit of the Gp. is the Basal Quartzite Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is cross-bedded, fine- to medium-grained, quartz arenite, although locally the base reaches pebble grade. Compositionally, the basal part is also feldspar rich, up to subarkose in places, but the proportion and grain size decreases rapidly upwards. The unit is overlain by cross-bedded quartz arenites of the Pipe Rock Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is a fine- to coarse-grained, quartz arenite with abundant Skolithos burrows at most levels. Localised staining by ferric iron oxide is present in the upper part of the Member, commonly differentially distributed between burrows and matrix. The Eriboll Fm. is conformably overlain by dolomitic siltstones, with minor dolomitic grainstones and dolomitic sandstones, of the Fucoid Beds Member (An t-Sron Fm.).  The Fucoid Beds Member is in turn overlain by the Salterella Grit Member (An t-Sron Fm.) which marks a return to cross-bedded quartz arenites containing Skolithos, but also containing abundant agglutinated shells of Salterella.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ARDV">ARDV</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone	An t-Sron Fm.	512.45	LITHOLOGY = Two distinctive members: dolomitic brown-coloured siltstone, mudstone and sandstone of the Fucoid Beds Member, and white quartz-sandstone of the Salterella Grit Member.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASR">ASR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at 65% up in stage 4 of the Cambrian.
	Sandstone	Eriboll Fm.	534.60	LITHOLOGY = Quartz-sandstone with a thin basal conglomerate.  Lower Basal Quartzite Member and upper Pipe Rock Member containing abundant Skolithos burrows.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ERSA">ERSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of stage 2 of the Cambrian.
 	Primary
	TOP		880.00	CALIBRATION = Drawn 80% up in the Tonian.

	Sandstone	Bearreraig Sandstone Fm.	175.97	LITHOLOGY = Consists of the Druim An Fhurain Sandstone Member (DAFS) and the Garantiana Mudstone Member (GaSh). See also the descriptions for these units. Three cycles of deposition; the first is cross-bedded sandstone and sandy limestones, deposited as tidal sand waves. The cross-bedded facies passes laterally to massive sandstones with doggers, then to upward-coarsening cycles of mudstone, siltstone and sandstone. The third facies consists of mudstones, silty and sandy limestones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BEAS">BEAS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 95% up in the Toarcian.

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Raasay Ironstone Fm.	179.03	LITHOLOGY = Dark siltstone (shale), ironstone and oolitic siltstone (shale). 	Fine-grained sandstone	Scalpay Sandstone Fm.	186.43	LITHOLOGY = Siltstones and sandstone, coarsening-upwards to fine-grained sandstone. CALIBRATION = 48% up in the Pliensbachian.
	Claystone	Pabay Shale Fm.	190.98	LITHOLOGY = Micaceous mudstones, rich in benthic faunas, ammonites and belemnites. Coarsens upwards to the Scalpay Sandstone Fm., with thin, local, clastic coarsening cycles.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PABS">PABS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in the Sinemurian.
	Clayey sandstone	Ardnish Fm.	195.47	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone, fissile micaceous mudstone, with thin ironstones in the lower section. Gryphaea common.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ADS">ADS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Sinemurian.
	Limestone	Breakish Fm.	199.14	LITHOLOGY = Lower half is micritic limestone and dark calcareous mudstones; upper half is bioclastic limestones, ooidal limestone and nodular limestones. Coral beds exist near Broadford.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRKH">BRKH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Hettangian.

New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. NOTE: In northeast England New Red Sandstone included only Sherwood Sandstone and Mercia Mudstone Gp.s: the Magnesian Limestone was used as a term of equal status. In the northwest the map clearly shows the unit extended down to the unconformable contact with Coal Measures, and so included the Permian red beds. In the south-west likewise.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NRS">NRS</a> ].

[For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ELD">ELD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Paibian.
	Dolomitic limestone	Ghrudaidh Fm.	508.25	LITHOLOGY = Dolostones containing oolitic and bioclastic grainstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=GUD">GUD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in Stage 5 of the Cambrian.
Ardvreck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The lowest unit of the Gp. is the Basal Quartzite Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is cross-bedded, fine- to medium-grained, quartz arenite, although locally the base reaches pebble grade. Compositionally, the basal part is also feldspar rich, up to subarkose in places, but the proportion and grain size decreases rapidly upwards. The unit is overlain by cross-bedded quartz arenites of the Pipe Rock Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is a fine- to coarse-grained, quartz arenite with abundant Skolithos burrows at most levels. Localised staining by ferric iron oxide is present in the upper part of the Member, commonly differentially distributed between burrows and matrix. The Eriboll Fm. is conformably overlain by dolomitic siltstones, with minor dolomitic grainstones and dolomitic sandstones, of the Fucoid Beds Member (An t-Sron Fm.).  The Fucoid Beds Member is in turn overlain by the Salterella Grit Member (An t-Sron Fm.) which marks a return to cross-bedded quartz arenites containing Skolithos, but also containing abundant agglutinated shells of Salterella.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ARDV">ARDV</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone	An t-Sron Fm.	512.45	LITHOLOGY = Two distinctive members: dolomitic siltstone, mudstone and sandstone of the Fucoid Beds Member, and quartz sandstone of the Salterella Grit Member.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASR">ASR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Stage 4 of the Cambrian.
	Sandstone	Eriboll Sandstone Fm.	534.60	LITHOLOGY = Quartz sandstone with a thin basal conglomerate.  Lower Basal Quartzite Member and upper Pipe Rock Member.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ERSA">ERSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Stage 2 in the Cambrian. The "sandstone" is left out of the name on the database. 
 	Primary
	TOP		982.00	CALIBRATION = 12% up in the Tonian.

	Coarse-grained sandstone	Applecross Fm.	1000.00	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TCA">TCA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Tonian.

 	Primary
	Sandstone	Bearreraig Sandstone Fm.	175.97	LITHOLOGY = Consists of the Druim An Fhurain Sandstone Member (DAFS) and the Garantiana Mudstone Member (GaSh). See also the descriptions for these units. Three cycles of deposition; the first is cross-bedded sandstone and sandy limestones, deposited as tidal sand waves. The cross-bedded facies passes laterally to massive sandstones with doggers, then to upward-coarsening cycles of mudstone, siltstone and sandstone. The third facies consists of mudstones, silty and sandy limestones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BEAS">BEAS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 95% up in the Toarcian.

	Gap		177.08	CALIBRATION = 80% up in the Toarcian.
Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Raasay Ironstone Fm.	179.03	LITHOLOGY = Dark siltstone (shale), ironstone and oolitic siltstone (shale).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RASI">RASI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Late Toarcian (C. Waters had assigned as 179 Ma using GTS04 scale)
	Claystone	Portree Shale Fm.	182.26	LITHOLOGY = Anoxic organic-rich mudstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEE">PEE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in the Toarcian.
	Fine-grained sandstone	Scalpay Sandstone Fm.	186.43	LITHOLOGY = Siltstones and sandstone, coarsening-upwards to fine-grained sandstone. Top is characterised by thin beds, ferriginous material and of chamosite-rich oolidal ironstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SCS">SCS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 48% up in the Pliensbachian.
	Claystone	Pabay Shale Fm.	190.98	LITHOLOGY = Micaceous mudstones, rich in benthic faunas, ammonites and belemnites. Coarsens upwards to the Scalpay Sandstone Fm., with thin, local, clastic coarsening cycles.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PABS">PABS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in the Sinemurian.
	Clayey sandstone	Ardnish Fm.	195.47	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone, fissile micaceous mudstone, with thin ironstones in the lower section. Gryphaea common.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ADS">ADS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Sinemurian.
	Limestone	Breakish Fm.	199.14	LITHOLOGY = Lower half is micritic limestone and dark calcareous mudstones; upper half is bioclastic limestones, ooidal limestone and nodular limestones. Coral beds exist near Broadford.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRKH">BRKH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Hettangian.
Penarth Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to black mudstones with subordinate limestones and sandstones; predominantly marine in origin.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PNG">PNG</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl		203.24	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones with limestones and sandstones; predominantly marine in origin.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PNG">PNG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in the Rhaetian.
New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. NOTE: In northeast England New Red Sandstone included only Sherwood Sandstone and Mercia Mudstone Gp.s: the Magnesian Limestone was used as a term of equal status. In the northwest the map clearly shows the unit extended down to the unconformable contact with Coal Measures, and so included the Permian red beds. In the south-west likewise.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NRS">NRS</a> ].

[For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ELD">ELD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Paibian.

Ardvreck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The lowest unit of the Gp. is the Basal Quartzite Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is cross-bedded, fine- to medium-grained, quartz arenite, although locally the base reaches pebble grade. Compositionally, the basal part is also feldspar rich, up to subarkose in places, but the proportion and grain size decreases rapidly upwards. The unit is overlain by cross-bedded quartz arenites of the Pipe Rock Member (Eriboll Fm.) which is a fine- to coarse-grained, quartz arenite with abundant Skolithos burrows at most levels. Localised staining by ferric iron oxide is present in the upper part of the Member, commonly differentially distributed between burrows and matrix. The Eriboll Fm. is conformably overlain by dolomitic siltstones, with minor dolomitic grainstones and dolomitic sandstones, of the Fucoid Beds Member (An t-Sron Fm.).  The Fucoid Beds Member is in turn overlain by the Salterella Grit Member (An t-Sron Fm.) which marks a return to cross-bedded quartz arenites containing Skolithos, but also containing abundant agglutinated shells of Salterella.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ARDV">ARDV</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone	An t-Sron Fm.	512.45	LITHOLOGY = Two distinctive members: dolomitic siltstone, mudstone and sandstone of the Fucoid Beds Member, and quartz sandstone of the Salterella Grit Member.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASR">ASR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Stage 4 of the Cambrian.
	Sandstone	Eriboll Sandstone Fm.	534.60	LITHOLOGY = Quartz sandstone with a thin basal conglomerate.  Lower Basal Quartzite Member and upper Pipe Rock Member.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ERSA">ERSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Stage 2 in the Cambrian. The "sandstone" is left out of the name on the database. 
 	Primary
	TOP		982.00	CALIBRATION = 12% up in the Tonian.

Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].

Residual Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Includes remanie deposits formed by weathering and solifluction of original Palaeogene bedrock and Neogene to Early Quaternary superficial deposits. Typical deposits include the Clay-with-Flints of southern Britain and the Buchan Gravels Fm. of northeastern Scotland.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RESID">RESID</a> ].  
	Conglomerate	Buchan Gravels Fm.	12.71	LITHOLOGY = Well rounded gravel and cobble gravel in white silty sand to sandy kaolinitic clay matrix.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BUG">BUG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = DASHED -- Drawn 50% up in the Serravillian
 	Primary
	TOP		113.30	CALIBRATION = DASHED -- Drawn 90% up in the Aptian
Cromer Knoll Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine-grained , argillaceous, marine sediments with a varying content of calcareous material.  Calcareous claystones, siltstones and marlstones dominate, but subordinate layers of limestones and sandstone occur.  The claystones are generally light to dark grey, olive-grey, greenish and brownish, often becoming light grey, light greenish grey and light olive-grey marlstones.  Mica, pyrite and glauconite are common.  Generally, marlstones become the more dominant lithology in both the upper and lower parts of the Gp..(Isaken and Tonstad, 1989).    [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRKN">CRKN</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Moreseat Sandstone Fm.	133.87	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, fine-grained, silty, glauconitic, very dark grey. Bioturbated with moulds of mollusca.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MOSA">MOSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = DASHED -- Drawn at the base of the Hauterivian
 	Primary
	TOP		189.60	CALIBRATION = DASHED -- Drawn near the base of the Pliensbachian
Sutherland Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey-green mudstone, siltstone and sandstone all of which are locally carbonaceous/bituminous, thin sandy limestones, ironstones, a thin coal, a basal conglomerate and boulder beds towards the TOP.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SUTH">SUTH</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Dunrobin Bay Fm.	196.50	LITHOLOGY = Sutherland Gp. is mudstone, siltstone and sandstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRB">DRB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = DASHED -- Drawn at the base of the Sinemurian

	Gap		200.81	CALIBRATION = Drawn 70% up in the Rhaetian
New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. NOTE: In northeast England New Red Sandstone included only Sherwood Sandstone and Mercia Mudstone Gp.s: the Magnesian Limestone was used as a term of equal status. In the northwest the map clearly shows the unit extended down to the unconformable contact with Coal Measures, and so included the Permian red beds. In the south-west likewise.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NRS">NRS</a> ].

Scottish Coal Measures Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Cyclic alternation of mudstone, siltstone and sandstone with common coal seams at some levels. NOTE: FORMERLY - (1) Upper (Barren) Coal Measures. (2) Productive Coal Measures (comprising Middle Coal Measures and Lower Coal Measures).  The terms "Barren" and "Productive" are misleading in a Scottish context and should be dropped.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CMSC">CMSC</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Scottish Upper Coal Measures	315.19	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone and mudstone in repeated cycles, most commonly fining upwards.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=UCMS">UCMS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 70% up in the Choklerian

Highland Border Complex	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Four distinct assemblages, all showing varying degrees of greenschist facies regional metamorphism: (4) gritty sandstone, limestone and mudstone (probably Caradoc); (3) metabasalt, chert and mudstone equivalents; (2) limestone and basal serpentinite conglomerate (mid-Arenig); (1) serpentinite, metagabbro and hornblende-schist.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HBX">HBX</a> ].  
	Dolomitic limestone	Dounans Limestone Fm.	471.43	LITHOLOGY = Limestone, massive; dolomitised and silicified over much of outcrop.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DSLM">DSLM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 10% up in the Dapingian

Appin Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Alternating units of psammite to quartzite and semipelite to pelite in Lochaber Subgroup. In the Ballachulish and Blair Atholl Subgroups, pelitic and calcareous lithologies dominate, although one clean-washed, locally pebbly quartzite in the Ballachulish Subgroup is persistent from Donegal to Banffshire. Many of the pelitic and calcareous rocks are graphitic.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=APP">APP</a> ].  
	Limestone	Lossit Limestone Fm.	645.75	LITHOLOGY = not details given  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DAIL">DAIL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 95% up in the Cryogenian

Residual Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Includes remanie deposits formed by weathering and solifluction of original Palaeogene bedrock and Neogene to Early Quaternary superficial deposits. Typical deposits include the Clay-with-Flints of southern Britain and the Buchan Gravels Fm. of northeastern Scotland.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RESID">RESID</a> ].

New Red Sandstone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Breccias, sandstones, mudstones (red-beds) component Gp.s: Mercia Mudstone Gp., Sherwood Sandstone Gp., Aylesbeare Mudstone Gp. and Exeter Gp.. NOTE: In northeast England New Red Sandstone included only Sherwood Sandstone and Mercia Mudstone Gp.s: the Magnesian Limestone was used as a term of equal status. In the northwest the map clearly shows the unit extended down to the unconformable contact with Coal Measures, and so included the Permian red beds. In the south-west likewise.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NRS">NRS</a> ].

Highland Border Complex	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Four distinct assemblages, all showing varying degrees of greenschist facies regional metamorphism, have so far been recognised: (4) gritty sandstone, limestone and mudstone (probably Caradoc); (3) metabasalt, chert and mudstone equivalents; (2) limestone and basal serpentinite conglomerate (mid-Arenig); (1) serpentinite, metagabbro and hornblende-schist. The status of associated limestone (Leny Limestone) and black shale is unclear (probably Early Cambrian).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HBX">HBX</a> ].  
	Dolomitic limestone	Dounans Limestone Fm.	471.43	LITHOLOGY = Limestone, massive; dolomitised and silicified over much of outcrop.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DSLM">DSLM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 10% up in the Dapingian
	Gap		479.57	CALIBRATION = Drawn 90% up in the Tremaocian
	Mixed marine	North Esk Fm.	484.89	LITHOLOGY = Three lithologies with oceanic affinities are juxtaposed: (i) metabasalt locally retaining pillows, (ii) chert, brownish, (iii) black slaty pelite  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NOE">NOE</a> ]. Appin Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Alternating units of psammite to quartzite and semipelite to pelite in Lochaber Subgroup. In the Ballachulish and Blair Atholl Subgroups, pelitic and calcareous lithologies dominate, although one clean-washed, locally pebbly quartzite in the Ballachulish Subgroup is persistent from Donegal to Banffshire. Many of the pelitic and calcareous rocks are graphitic.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=APP">APP</a> ].

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].

	Sandy claystone	Auchenhew Mudstone Fm.	238.78	LITHOLOGY = Intertidal and tidal-flat facies with halite pseudomorphs within sandstones, siltstones and mudstones comprise the majority of the succession. Bimodal palaeocurrents, symmetrical ripples, flaser and wavy bedforms are common. Trace fossils are also commonly found. Stewartry Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Thick and very thick sequences of red sandstone and sedimentary breccias, some with evidence of basaltic lavas at or near the base of the sequence, deposited within separate fault-defined or fault-controlled basins e.g. Stranraer [Stone, 1988]. Breccia Fm.s may be present at the base of the Stewartry Gp.. They are either overlain by sandstone Fm.s or breccia and sandstone Fm.s occur in an intertonguing relationship. Basaltic lava may also be present at or near the base of the Gp..  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STEW">STEW</a> ].  
	Conglomerate	Brodick Breccia Fm.	271.10	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRDB">BRDB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Kiungurian.  DASHED
	Sandstone	Corrie Sandstone Fm.	293.07	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CSS">CSS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Sakmarian. DASHED

Balcreuchan Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = An interbedded succession of basaltic pillow lava (some are boninitic) and breccia, agglomerate, volcaniclastic sandstone, tuff, siltstone, conglomerate and mudstone-supported melange, and hyaloclastite. Locally sheared and metamorphosed to amphibolitic schist and chlorite-epidote schist. The dominant lavas are contained in faulted, tectonic blocks and are not, for the most part, formally defined as Fm.s. There is good stratigraphical correlation between some of the blocks, but connections are generally tenuous. A number of the more distinctive lithological units have been defined formally as Fm.s.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCN">BCN</a> ].  
	Lava		501.00	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCN">BCN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Paibian.
 	Primary

Stewartry Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Thick and very thick sequences of red sandstone and sedimentary breccias, some with evidence of basaltic lavas at or near the base of the sequence, deposited within separate fault-defined or fault-controlled basins e.g. Stranraer [Stone, 1988]. Breccia Fm.s may be present at the base of the Stewartry Gp.. They are either overlain by sandstone Fm.s or breccia and sandstone Fm.s occur in an intertonguing relationship. Basaltic lava may also be present at or near the base of the Gp..  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STEW">STEW</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Mauchline Sandstone Fm.	298.12	LITHOLOGY = Red quartz-rich sandstone (dunes)  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MSS">MSS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Asselian.

Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstones containing pedogenic limestone and dolomite nodules ('cornstones'), fine-grained carbonate as beds, nodules and pebbles, and grey and brown mudstones containing thin beds of limestone and dolomite ('cementstones'); subordinate siltstone and mudstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=INV">INV</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Clyde Sandstone Fm.	347.93	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, commonly pebbly with beds of red-brown or grey mudstone. Pedogenic carbonate as nodules and beds especially in lower part.   For URL constructionCYDCYDCALIBRATION = Base of the Chadian.
	Claystone	Ballagan Fm.	349.85	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones and siltstones, with nodules and beds of ferroan dolomite (cementstones), gypsum and, to a much lesser extent, anhydrite and pseudomorphs after halite occur. Desiccation cracks are common.  For URL constructionBGNBGNCALIBRATION = 83% up in the Courceyan.
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Kinnesswood Fm.	359.51	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone with carbonate (limestone or dolomite) nodular pedogenic horizons (cornstone).   For URL constructionKNWKNWCALIBRATION = 98% up in the Famennian.
 	Primary
	Gap		360.73	CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Famennian.
Stratheden Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, mainly red-brown and yellow, partly pebbly; subordinate red-brown siltstone and mudstone; local thick conglomerates in the west.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SAG">SAG</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Fairie Sandstone Fomation	365.32	LITHOLOGY = Pebbly sandstone.  For URL constructionKBSKBSCALIBRATION = 60% up in the Famennian.
	Conglomerate	Skelmorlie Conglomerate Fm.	369.91	LITHOLOGY = Conglomerate with clasts of quartz, schist, quartzite and lava and interbeds of pebbly sandstone.   For URL constructionSKMSKMCALIBRATION = 30% up in the Famennian.
	Conglomerate	Wemyss Bay Sandstone Fm.	374.50	LITHOLOGY = Cross-bedded, fine-grained sandstone.   For URL constructionWEMWEMCALIBRATION = Base of the Famennian. DASHED
 	Primary
	Top		397.50	CALIBRATION = Base of Eifelian
Strathmore Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded sandstone and siltstone. These interfinger with clast-supported conglomerate containing well-rounded boulders, cobbles and pebbles predominantly of psammite, quartzite and lava in areas adjacent to the Highland Boundary Fault. Siltstone and mudstone are interbedded with the sandstone, particularly in Strathallan.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SEG">SEG</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone		408.18	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded sandstone and siltstone interfinger with conglomerate.  For URL constructionSEGSEGCALIBRATION = 72% up in the Pragian.
Arbuthnott-Garvock Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstone predominates, interbedded with clast-supported conglomerate with well-rounded boulders, cobbles and pebbles predominantly of lava, psammite and quartzite in the northeast and adjacent to the Highland Boundary Fault. Siltstone and mudstone are interbedded with the sandstone, e.g. in the Dundee area and Strathallan. Piles of andesitic, basaltic and rhyolitic lavas, locally very thick, are interbedded with conglomerate and sandstone in many areas. Lenses and thicker Fm.s of volcaniclastic sandstone are interbedded with conglomerate in the Stonehaven area and are associated with lavas elsewhere. Calcrete near top in many areas.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ATGL">ATGL</a> ].  
	Conglomerate		409.10	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionATGLATGLCALIBRATION = 50% up in the Pragian.
	Volcanics		409.94	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionATGLATGLCALIBRATION = 30% up in the Pragian.
	Conglomerate		415.09	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionATGLATGLCALIBRATION = 19% up in the Lochkovian. 
Dunnottar-Crawton Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Conglomerate, clast-supported, with angular to well-rounded boulders, cobbles and pebbles. In the lower part these consist predominantly of lava, psammite and quartzite, but in the upper part the conglomerates are of markedly different provenance and were deposited from streams flowing in opposing directions. Poorly-sorted volcaniclastic sandstone and conglomerate are interbedded with non-volcaniclastic conglomerate. Non-volcaniclastic deposits consist of poorly-sorted conglomerate, with angular clasts, and bimodally-sorted conglomerate with rounded clasts. Flows of trachybasalt, trachyandesite and andesitic lava occur in the lower and middle parts of the Gp.. The top of the Dunnottar-Crawton Gp. is characterised by the intermittent occurrence of volcanic rocks including trachybasaltic lavas and welded dacitic tuff (Lintrathen Tuff Member).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRCR">DRCR</a> ].  
	Conglomerate		418.16	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionDRCRDRCRCALIBRATION = 20% up in the Pridoli
	Volcanics		419.22	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionDRCRDRCRCALIBRATION = 80% up in the Ludfordian.
	Conglomerate		420.00	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionDRCRDRCRCALIBRATION = 50% up in the Ludfordian.
Stonehaven Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained lithic sandstone interbedded with minor amounts of conglomerate and siltstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SHG">SHG</a> ].  
	Sandstone		425.21	LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained lithic sandstone.  For URL constructionSHGSHGCALIBRATION = 30% up in the Homerian.

Balcreuchan Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = An interbedded succession of basaltic pillow lava (some are boninitic) and breccia, agglomerate, volcaniclastic sandstone, tuff, siltstone, conglomerate and mudstone-supported melange, and hyaloclastite. Locally sheared and metamorphosed to amphibolitic schist and chlorite-epidote schist. The dominant lavas are contained in faulted, tectonic blocks and are not, for the most part, formally defined as Fm.s. There is good stratigraphical correlation between some of the blocks, but connections are generally tenuous. A number of the more distinctive lithological units have been defined formally as Fm.s.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCN">BCN</a> ].  
	Lava		501.00	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  For URL constructionBCNBCNCALIBRATION = Base of the Paibian.
 	Primary

Stewartry Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Thick and very thick sequences of red sandstone and sedimentary breccias, some with evidence of basaltic lavas at or near the base of the sequence, deposited within separate fault-defined or fault-controlled basins e.g. Stranraer [Stone, 1988]. Breccia Fm.s may be present at the base of the Stewartry Gp.. They are either overlain by sandstone Fm.s or breccia and sandstone Fm.s occur in an intertonguing relationship. Basaltic lava may also be present at or near the base of the Gp..  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STEW>STEW</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Locharbriggs Sandstone Fm.	284.40	LITHOLOGY = Dune sandstone; very well sorted.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LCH>LCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Artinskian.

Border Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The Border Gp. comprises interbedded sandstones, siltstones and limestones, with conglomerate and ferroan dolostone ("cementstone"). Component Fm.s include the Lyne Fm. , which comprises siltstone and dolostone with fine-grained sandstone, and the Fell Sandstone Fm., which comprises medium- to coarse-grained sandstone with siltstone and subsidiary fine-grained conglomerate and dolostone. Some members of the Lyne Fm. are notable for their algal beds (eg the Main Algal Member). The Kershopefoot Basalt Beds are thin olivine-basalt flows within the Fell Sandstone Fm..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BDR>BDR</a> ].

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Cumbrian Coast Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Comprises a basal sequence of grey siltstones and dolomites overlain by evaporites (St Bees Evaporite Fm.), overlain by red siltstones, silty mudstones and calcareous sandstones (St Bees Shale Fm.), which locally pass laterally into halite.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CCO>CCO</a> ].  
	Gypsiferous claystone	Eden Shales Fm.	272.35	LITHOLOGY = Red shales and mudstones with local beds of gypsum and anhydrite, rare dolomitic limestones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=EDSH>EDSH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in the Kungurian.
Appleby Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Red, aeolian cross-bedded millet-seed sandstone, fluviatile sandstone and breccias ('Brockram') interbedded in varying proportions. In the Collyhurst Sandstone and correlatives grey, white and pale brown colours are also common and breccias are rare. Some interbedded red mudstones are present locally.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=APY>APY</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Penrith Sandstone Fm.	290.01	LITHOLOGY = Coarse-grained cross-bedded aeolian sandstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PS>PS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in the Sakmarian.
 	Primary
	TOP		307.21	CALIBRATION = Base of the Stephanian.
Warwickshire Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly red, brown or purple-grey sandstone, siltstone and mudstone, some grey strata, coals not common, local conglomerates, localised beds of Spirorbis limestone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK>WAWK</a> ].  
	Sandstone		309.57	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone and mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK>WAWK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in the Westphalian.
Pennine Coal Measures Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Alternation of sandstone, grey siltstone and grey mudstone, with frequent coal seams and seatearth horizons.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PCM>PCM</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Upper Coal Measures	311.25	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstone, siltstone and pale grey sandstone, commonly with coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PUCM>PUCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Middle Coal Measures	313.94	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstone, siltstone and pale grey sandstone, commonly with coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PMCM>PMCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of  the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Lower Coal Measures	314.90	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstone, siltstone and pale grey sandstone, commonly with coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PLCM>PLCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Yeasdonian
Yoredale Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=YORE>YORE</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Stainmore Fm.	317.21	LITHOLOGY = Cyclical repetition of sandstones, siltstones, mudstones, thin limestones and some coals.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SMGP>SMGP</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Kinderscoutian. Guide moved to the beginning of column 4. 
	Sandy claystone	Stainmore Fm.	326.40	LITHOLOGY = Cyclical repetition of sandstones, siltstones, mudstones, thin limestones and some coals. 	Continental marl	Alston Fm.	331.34	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous claystone -- bioclastic limestones, sandstones, mudstones, siltstones and rare coals typically in regular cyclothemic sequence.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AG>AG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 5% up in the Brigantian. Base of the Gp. overlaps with the top of the Great Scar Limestone Gp.
	Sandy claystone	Tyne Limestone Fm.	335.64	LITHOLOGY = Despite the 'limestone' name, the Tyne is "Sandstone, siltstone, seatearth and thin limestone; locally thin coals and volcanic tuffs and basalt lavas."  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TYLS>TYLS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 5% up in the Asbian.
Border Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = The Border Gp. comprises interbedded sandstones, siltstones and limestones, with conglomerate and ferroan dolostone ("cementstone"). Component formations include the Lyne Fm. , which comprises siltstone and dolostone with fine-grained sandstone, and the Fell Sandstone Fm., which comprises medium- to coarse-grained sandstone with siltstone and subsidiary fine-grained conglomerate and dolostone. Some members of the Lyne Fm. are notable for their algal beds (eg the Main Algal Member). The Kershopefoot Basalt Beds are thin olivine-basalt flows within the Fell Sandstone Fm..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BDR>BDR</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Fell Sandstone Fm.	342.94	LITHOLOGY = Cross-bedded sandstone, locally conglomeratic, with siltstone, mudstone, seatearth and locally developed thin coals and limestones [onshore areas].   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FELL>FELL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Arundian.
	Sandy claystone	Lyne Fm.	344.44	LITHOLOGY = Cyclical sequences of sandstone, siltstone, mudstone and thin limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LYNE>LYNE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 70% up in the Chadian.
Inverclyde Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstones containing pedogenic limestone and dolomite nodules ('cornstones'), fine-grained carbonate as beds, nodules and pebbles, and grey and brown mudstones containing thin beds of limestone and dolomite ('cementstones'); subordinate siltstone and mudstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=INV>INV</a> ].  
	Claystone	Ballagan Fm.	350.41	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones and siltstones, with nodules and beds of ferroan dolomite (cementstones). Gypsum and, to a much lesser extent, anhydrite and pseudomorphs after halite occur.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BGN>BGN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 78% up in the Courceyan.
	Lava	Cottonshope Volcanic Fm.	356.38	LITHOLOGY = Basalt, olivine-phyric, tholeiitic.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COVO>COVO</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 25% up in the Courceyan.
	Sandstone	Kinnesswood Fm.	359.97	LITHOLOGY = Characteristically sandstone with carbonate nodular pedogenic horizons (cornstone).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KNW>KNW</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 95% up in the Famennian.

	TOP		394.08	CALIBRATION = 61% up in the Eifelian.

	Fine-grained sandstone	Kirkby Moor Fm.	420.00	LITHOLOGY = Thick beds of massive or convulate laminated, and thin-bedded ripple-cross laminated, fine-grained sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KMF>KMF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Ludfordian.

Stockdale Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dominantly mudstone and siltstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STK>STK</a> ].  
	Siltstone	Browgill Fm.	435.31	LITHOLOGY = Laminated mudstone, siltstone and calcareous shale.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRW>BRW</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in the Telychian.

Dent Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Varied assemblage of shallow marine clastic lithologies and limestone, pyroclastic rocks and rhyolitic lava.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DNT>DNT</a> ].  
	Claystone	Ashgill Fm.	446.92	LITHOLOGY = Dark blue-grey shales, distinguished from underlying Fm.s of the Coniston Limestone Gp. by its lower calcareous content and the near absence of limestone nodules. Dark silty mudstones are commonly pervasively bioturbated.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AHL>AHL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 55% up in the Ashgill.
	Continental marl	Cautley Mudstone Fm.	451.35	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous mudstone with impersistent limestone beds; includes units of sandstone at the base and higher in the succession [Wilsey Beck Sandstone Member]; also of rhyolitic tuff [Cautley Volcanic Member].   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CMU>CMU</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 95% up in the Caradoc.

Cumbrian Coast Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Comprises a basal sequence of grey siltstones and dolomites overlain by evaporites (St Bees Evaporite Fm.), overlain by red siltstones, silty mudstones and calcareous sandstones (St Bees Shale Fm.), which locally pass laterally into halite. 	Gypsiferous claystone	Eden Shales Fm.	272.35	LITHOLOGY = Red shales and mudstones with local beds of gypsum and anhydrite, rare dolomitic limestones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=EDSH>EDSH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in the Kungurian.
Appleby Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Red, aeolian cross-bedded millet-seed sandstone, fluviatile sandstone and breccias ('Brockram') interbedded in varying proportions. In the Collyhurst Sandstone and correlatives grey, white and pale brown colours are also common and breccias are rare. Some interbedded red mudstones are present locally.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=APY>APY</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Penrith Sandstone Fm.	291.54	LITHOLOGY = Coarse-grained cross-bedded aeolian sandstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PS>PS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in the Sakmarian.
	Conglomerate	Brockram Fm.	294.60	LITHOLOGY = Fluviatile sandstone and breccias ('Brockram')  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=></a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Sakmarian.

	TOP		307.21	CALIBRATION = Base of the Stephanian.
Warwickshire Gp. 	Sandy claystone	Pennine Upper Coal Measures	311.25	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstone, siltstone and pale grey sandstone, commonly with coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PUCM>PUCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in the Westphalian.

Left column (region S2)	facies	100	234/201/201			Waters, C.N. et al (16 authors), 2007.  Stratigraphical Chart of the United Kingdom: 2 sheets -- Northern Britain & Southern Britain. British Geological Survey, 2 posters.
Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT>BCAT</a> ].  
	TOP		0.00	CALIBRATION = Drawn at the present
	Coarse-grained sandstone		0.01	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT>BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the Holocene
Caledonia Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI>CALI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.13	LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI>CALI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the Late Pleistocene
Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT>BCAT</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone		0.52	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT>BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 40% up in the middle Pleistocene
Albion Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI>ALBI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.78	LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI>ALBI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the middle Pleistocene
 	Primary
	TOP		178.56	CALIBRATION = 60% up in the Toarcian.
Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI>LI</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl		200.41	LITHOLOGY = Marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI>LI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in the Rhaetian.
Penarth Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to black mudstones with subordinate limestones and sandstones; predominantly marine in origin.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PNG>PNG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Lilstock Fm.	201.82	LITHOLOGY = Includes Cotham Member (shales and siltstones) and Langport Member (porcellanous limestone below, calcareous mudstone above).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LTK>LTK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in the Rhaetian.
	Claystone	Westbury Fm.	203.64	LITHOLOGY = Dark grey mudstones or shales with thin limestones, sandstones and fossiferous arenaceous ('bone beds').   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WBY>WBY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Rhaetian.
Mercia Mudstone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dominantly red, less commonly green-grey, mudstones and subordinate siltstones with thick halite-bearing units in some basinal areas.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MMG>MMG</a> ].  
	Continental marl	Blue Anchor Fm.	206.73	LITHOLOGY = Pale green-grey, dolomitic silty mudstones and siltstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BAN>BAN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 76% up in the Norian.
	Gypsiferous claystone	Branscombe Mudstone Fm.	217.51	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone and siltstone, red-brown with common grey-green reduction patches.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCMU>BCMU</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 92% up in the Carnian. 
	Gypsiferous claystone	Sidmouth Mudstone Fm.	240.47	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone and siltstone, red-brown with common grey-green reduction patches.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SIM>SIM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 61% up the Anisian. 
	Siltstone	Tarporley Siltstone Fm.	242.52	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded siltstones, mudstones and sandstones in approximately equal proportions.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TPSF>TPSF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 38% up in the Anisian.
Sherwood Sandstone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, red, yellow and brown, part pebbly; subordinate red mudstone and siltstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SSG>SSG</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Helsby Sandstone Fm.	245.63	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone-dominated, with sporadic conglomerates, particularly towards the base, and siltstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HEY>HEY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 3% up in the Anisian. 
	Sandstone	Wilmslow Sandstone Fm.	247.88	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, fine- to medium-grained.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WLSF>WLSF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in the Olenekian.
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Chester Pebble Beds Fm.	249.21	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, commonly pebbly, with conglomerates and sporadic siltstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CPB>CPB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 8% up in the Olenekian.
	Fine-grained sandstone	Kinnerton Sandstone Fm.	251.00	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, fine- to medium-grained. Dominantly aeolian.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KNSF>KNSF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Induan.
Cumbrian Coast Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Comprises a basal sequence of grey siltstones and dolomites overlain by evaporites (St Bees Evaporite Fm.), overlain by red siltstones, silty mudstones and calcareous sandstones (St Bees Shale Fm.), which locally pass laterally into halite.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CCO>CCO</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl	Manchester Marls Fm.	258.09	LITHOLOGY = Red marl (calcareous mudstone and siltstone) with thin beds of fossiliferous marine limestone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MM>MM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 35% up in the Wuchiapingian. 
Appleby Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Red, aeolian cross-bedded millet-seed sandstone, fluviatile sandstone and breccias ('Brockram') interbedded in varying proportions.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=APY>APY</a> ].  
	Sandstone	Collyhurst Sandstone Fm.	266.90	LITHOLOGY = Red sandstone with abundant beds of "millet seed" sand grains alternating with beds of fine-grained sharp sand.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CS>CS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Wordian. DASHED.
 	Primary
	TOP		307.21	CALIBRATION = Base of the Stephanian.
Warwickshire Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly red, brown or purple-grey sandstone, siltstone and mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK>WAWK</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Halesowen Fm.	308.62	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone and mudstone, with thin coals and limestone beds known as the 'Spirobis' limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HA>HA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 79% up in the Westphalian.
	Claystone	Etruria Fm.	311.25	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, with pedogenic horizons, but coal seams are rare.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ETM>ETM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in the Westphalian.
Pennine Coal Measures Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Alternation of sandstone, grey siltstone and grey mudstone, with frequent coal seams and seatearth horizons.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PCM>PCM</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Upper Coal Measures Fm.	312.59	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone and sandstone, commonly with coal seams.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PUCM>PUCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Middle Coal Measures Fm.	313.94	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone,  sandstone and commonly coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PMCM>PMCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Lower Coal Measures Fm.	314.42	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone and sandstone, with more numerous and thicker coal seams in the upper part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PLCM>PLCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Yeasdonian.
Millstone Grit Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine- to very coarse-grained feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones, with subordinate marine shaly mudstone, claystone, coals and seatearths.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MG>MG</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Rossendale Fm.	315.43	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone, interbedded with grey siltstone and mudstone. Typically, lower is mudstone-dominated and upper is sandstone-dominated  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ROSSE>ROSSE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Marsdenian.
	Sandy claystone	Marsden Fm.	316.09	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MARSD>MARSD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Kinderscoutian.
	Clayey sandstone	Hebden Fm.	317.25	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone interbedded with siltstone and mudstone. The lower part is dominated by a turbiditic facies; the upper part is dominated by sheet-like sandstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HEBD>HEBD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Alportian.
	Claystone	Samlesbury Fm.	318.10	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone.  In the Bradford area, a thick sandstone (Brocka Bank Grit).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SAML>SAML</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Chokerian.
	Sandy claystone	Silsden Fm.	322.74	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone with interbedded mudstone. The lower part is interpreted as turbiditic origin.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SILS>SILS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in the Arnsbergian.
	Sandy claystone	Pendleton Fm.	326.40	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PENDL>PENDL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Pendleian.
Craven Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to dark grey, siliciclastic to calcareous mudstone, limestone packstone and wackestone in sharp-based beds, with localised sandstone, siltstone and chert and mudmound reef limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAV>CRAV</a> ].  
	Claystone	Bowland Shale Fm.	332.24	LITHOLOGY = Mainly mudstone, weakly calcareous, with limestone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BSG>BSG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Pendleside Limestone Fm.	335.00	LITHOLOGY = Bioclastic, cherty packstones, interbedded with wackestone, sporadic limestone conglomerate, and especially in the lower part, mudstone (Rad Brook Mudstone Member).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PDL>PDL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Hodderense Limestone Fm.	335.35	LITHOLOGY = Porcellanous wackestones with dark blue, micritic nodules, sporadic interbedded packstones and common mudstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOH>BOH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up Holkerian.
	Claystone	Hodder Mudstone Fm.	344.44	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, with detrital limestone, siltstone and sandstone. Mudmound reef (Waulsortian) limestones locally, near the base.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HOM>HOM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 70% up in the Chadian.
Bowland High Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Pale to dark grey, packstone and wackestone with subordinate grainstones, partings and thin beds of calcareous mudstone and calcareous siltstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOHI>BOHI</a> ].  
	Reef limestone	Clitheroe Limestone Fm.	346.88	LITHOLOGY = Coarsely crinoidal, packstones, wackestones with Waulsortian mudmound reef limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CLL>CLL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 21% up in the Chadian.
	Siliceous limestone	Chatburn Limestone Fm.	359.20	LITHOLOGY = Packstone limestones with chert lenses and partings of calcareous mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CHL>CHL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Courceyan. DASHED.
 	Primary
	TOP		416.00	CALIBRATION = Base of Lochkovian. DASHED.

Cumbrian Coast Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Comprises a basal sequence of grey siltstones and dolomites overlain by evaporites (St Bees Evaporite Fm.), overlain by red siltstones, silty mudstones and calcareous sandstones (St Bees Shale Fm.), which locally pass laterally into halite. 	Fine-grained sandstone	Bold Fm.	258.09	LITHOLOGY = No details given. Assumed to be same as general Cumbrian Gp. (siltstone with evaporites)  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOLD>BOLD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 35% up in the Wuchiapingian.

Millstone Grit Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine- to very coarse-grained feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones, with subordinate marine shaly mudstone, claystone, coals and seatearths.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MG>MG</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Rossendale Fm.	315.43	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone, interbedded with grey siltstone and mudstone. Typically, lower is mudstone-dominated and upper is sandstone-dominated  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ROSSE>ROSSE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Marsdenian.
	Sandy claystone	Marsden Fm.	316.09	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MARSD>MARSD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Kinderscoutian.
	Clayey sandstone	Hebden Fm.	317.25	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone interbedded with siltstone and mudstone. The lower part is dominated by a turbiditic facies; the upper part is dominated by sheet-like sandstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HEBD>HEBD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in the Alportian.
	Claystone	Samlesbury Fm.	318.10	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone.  In the Bradford area, a thick sandstone (Brocka Bank Grit).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SAML>SAML</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Chokerian.
	Sandy claystone	Silsden Fm.	322.74	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone with interbedded mudstone. The lower part is interpreted as turbiditic origin.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SILS>SILS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in the Arnsbergian.
	Sandy claystone	Pendleton Fm.	326.40	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PENDL>PENDL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Pendleian.
Craven Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to dark grey, siliciclastic to calcareous mudstone, limestone packstone and wackestone in sharp-based beds, with localised sandstone, siltstone and chert and mudmound reef limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAV>CRAV</a> ].  
	Claystone	Bowland Shale Fm.	332.24	LITHOLOGY = Mainly mudstone, weakly calcareous, with limestone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BSG>BSG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Pendleside Limestone Fm.	335.00	LITHOLOGY = Bioclastic, cherty packstones, interbedded with wackestone, sporadic limestone conglomerate, and especially in the lower part, mudstone (Rad Brook Mudstone Member).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PDL>PDL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Hodderense Limestone Fm.	335.35	LITHOLOGY = Porcellanous wackestones with dark blue, micritic nodules, sporadic interbedded packstones and common mudstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOH>BOH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up Holkerian.
	Claystone	Hodder Mudstone Fm.	342.61	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, with detrital limestone, siltstone and sandstone. Mudmound reef (Waulsortian) limestones locally, near the base. Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to dark grey, siliciclastic to calcareous mudstone, limestone packstone and wackestone in sharp-based beds, with localised sandstone, siltstone and chert and mudmound reef limestones.
