Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  
	TOP		0.0000	CALIBRATION = Drawn at the present
	Coarse-grained sandstone		0.0115	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the Holocene
Caledonia Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI">CALI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.13	LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI">CALI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn at the base of the Late Pleistocene
Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone		0.52	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 40% up in the middle Pleistocene

Dunwich Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial gravels with subsidiary sands, clays and silts.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DUNW">DUNW</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Bytham Sand and Gravel Fm.	1.45	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the Bytham River. Commonly a basal gravel is overlain by red fine- to medium-grained sand.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BYTH">BYTH</a> ]. Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl amd marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Siliceous chalk	Welton Chalk Fm.	94.46	LITHOLOGY = White, massive chalk with flint nodules; sporadic marl seams including basal Plenus Marls Member ("Black Band"). Named marl and flint bands.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WCK">WCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in the Cenomanian.
	Chalk	Ferriby Chalk Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Grey, soft, marly, flint-free chalk  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FYCK">FYCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Cenomanian.
 	Primary
	Chalk	Hunstanton Fm.	108.28	LITHOLOGY = Rubbly to massive chalks with marl bands; typically pink to brick-red in colour (due to disseminated hematite); Somewhat sandy, particularly in lower part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HUCK">HUCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in the Albian.
	Sandstone	Carstone Fm.	112.00	LITHOLOGY = Greenish-brown [rusty when weathered], massive cross-bedded, oolitic ferruginous sandstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CA">CA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Albian.

	Pelagic marl	Tealby Fm.	131.14	LITHOLOGY = Brown and grey clays, oolitic and glauconitic in part, with a sandy limestone in the middle part of the Fm..  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TBF">TBF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 70% up in the Hauterivian.

	Coarse-grained sandstone	Spilsby Sandstone Fm.	149.77	LITHOLOGY = Upper Spilsby Sandstone Member is pebble sandstone with iron ooliths, with a bed of phosphatic nodules and chert pebbles at the base.  Lower Spilsby Sandstone Member is coarse-grained, pebbly, glauconitic sands.  See URL for details.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SYS">SYS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Tithonian.

Ancholme Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AMG">AMG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	155.65	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous, kerogen-rich, or silty); thin siltstone and cementstone beds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Kimmeridgian

	Sandy claystone	Kellaways Fm.	164.74	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, grey, sandy, with calcareous siltstone and sandstone in upper part.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KLB">KLB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Callovian.

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Whitby Mudstone Fm.	181.52	LITHOLOGY = Fossiliferous mudstone and siltstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WHM">WHM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Toarcian.

(formerly the Permian Upper Marls) in type area and similar relationship elsewhere, but sharp and unconformable on Carboniferous or older rocks locally. In Devon, taken at the base of the Budleigh Salterton Pebble Beds Fm..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SSG">SSG</a> ].

Warwickshire Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly red, brown or purple-grey sandstone, siltstone and mudstone, some grey strata, coals not common, local conglomerates, localised beds of Spirorbis limestone. 	Sandy claystone	Pennine Lower Coal Measures Fm.	314.42	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone and sandstone, with more numerous and thicker coal seams in the upper part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PLCM">PLCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Yeadonian.
Millstone Grit Gp. 	Clayey sandstone	Rossendale Fm.	315.43	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone, interbedded with siltstone and mudstone. Craven Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to dark grey, siliciclastic to calcareous mudstone, limestone packstone and wackestone in sharp-based beds, with localised sandstone, siltstone and chert and mudmound reef limestones. Fm.s are typically defined by variations in abundance of mudstone and limestone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAV">CRAV</a> ].  
	Claystone	Bowland Shale Fm.	323.72	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, weakly calcareous, with limestone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BSG">BSG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in the Pendleian.
	Continental marl	Widmerpool Fm.	326.40	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, thinly interbedded with turbidite, clayey cherty limestone and siltstone, sandstone and tuff.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WDF">WDF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Pendleian.
Peak Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A thick sequence of pale to dark grey, thinly to thickly bedded biosparite and cherty micritic limestone units displaying knoll-reefs, comprising fossiliferous, massive micrite with localised common spar-filled cavities, and grey-brown to dark grey dolomitic limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PKLM">PKLM</a> ].  
	Siliceous limestone	Eyam Limestone Fm.	329.78	LITHOLOGY = Cherty, bioclastic limestone and a few dark mudstone intercalations.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=EYL">EYL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 35% up in the Brigantian.
	Limestone	Monsal Dale Limestone Fm.	332.45	LITHOLOGY = Well-sorted biosparites and pelsparites, to poorly sorted biomicrites.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MO">MO</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Bee Low Limestone Fm.	334.79	LITHOLOGY = Grainstones, thick-bedded, but biopelsparites and pelsparites also occur.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BLL">BLL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 25% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Woo Dale Limestone Fm.	338.87	LITHOLOGY = Basal volcanic breccia, overlain by limestone, including thin calcilutite beds and shale partings.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WDL">WDL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Holkerian.
	Gap	Woo Dale Limestone Fm.	342.28	CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Arundian.

Warwickshire Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly red, brown or purple-grey sandstone, siltstone and mudstone, some grey strata, coals not common, local conglomerates, localised beds of Spirorbis limestone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK">WAWK</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Halesowen Fm.	308.69	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone and mudstone, with thin coals and limestone beds known as the 'Spirobis' limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HA">HA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 78% up in the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Etruria Fm.	311.25	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, with pedogenic horizons, but coal seams are rare.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ETM">ETM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in the Westphalian.
Pennine Coal Measures Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Alternation of sandstone, grey siltstone and grey mudstone, with frequent coal seams and seatearth horizons.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PCM">PCM</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Upper Coal Measures Fm.	312.59	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone and sandstone, commonly with coal seams.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PUCM">PUCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in the Westphalian.
	Sandy claystone	Pennine Middle Coal Measures Fm.	313.94	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, siltstone,  sandstone and commonly coal seams.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PMCM">PMCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Westphalian.
	Lava		314.42	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Yeadonian.
Millstone Grit Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fine- to very coarse-grained feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones, with subordinate marine shaly mudstone, claystone, coals and seatearths.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MG">MG</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Rossendale Fm.	315.43	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstone, interbedded with siltstone and mudstone. Typically, lower is mudstone-dominated and upper is sandstone-dominated  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ROSSE">ROSSE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in the Marsdenian.
	Sandy claystone	Marsden Fm.	315.96	LITHOLOGY = Feldspathic sandstones, interbedded with grey siltstones and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MARSD">MARSD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Marsdenian.
Craven Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to dark grey, siliciclastic to calcareous mudstone, limestone packstone and wackestone in sharp-based beds, with localised sandstone, siltstone and chert and mudmound reef limestones. Fm.s are typically defined by variations in abundance of mudstone and limestone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAV">CRAV</a> ].  
	Claystone	Bowland Shale Fm.	319.65	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, weakly calcareous, with limestone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BSG">BSG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 70% up in the Arnsbergian.
	Lava	Bowland Shale Fm.	321.71	LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in the Arnsbergian.
	Claystone	Bowland Shale Fm.	323.72	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, weakly calcareous, with limestone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BSG">BSG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in the Pendleian.
	Continental marl	Widmerpool Fm.	329.52	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, thinly interbedded with turbidite, clayey cherty limestone and siltstone, sandstone and tuff.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WDF">WDF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in the Brigantian.
Peak Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A thick sequence of pale to dark grey, thinly to thickly bedded biosparite and cherty micritic limestone units displaying knoll-reefs, comprising fossiliferous, massive micrite with localised common spar-filled cavities, and grey-brown to dark grey dolomitic limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PKLM">PKLM</a> ].  
	Limestone	Hopedale Limestone Fm.	330.30	LITHOLOGY = Grainstones, with limestone clasts and coarse crinoid debris common at the base of the Fm., and in the vicinity of knoll-reefs.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HP">HP</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 25% up in the Brigantian.
	Lava	Hopedale Limestone Fm.	331.60	LITHOLOGY = Volcanic interval within Fm.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HP">HP</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Brigantian.
	Volcanics	Hopedale Limestone Fm.	333.30	LITHOLOGY = Volcanic interval within Fm.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HP">HP</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in the Asbian.
	Limestone	Hopedale Limestone Fm.	335.21	LITHOLOGY = Grainstones, with limestone clasts and coarse crinoid debris common at the base of the Fm., and in the vicinity of knoll-reefs.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HP">HP</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in the Asbian.
	Gap		335.85	CALIBRATION = Base of the Asbian.
	Reef limestone	Milldale Limestone Fm.	344.94	LITHOLOGY = Crinoidal "biosparites" and cherty micrites of an inter-reef facies, passing vertically and laterally into knoll reef mud-mounds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MI">MI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in the Chadian.
	Evaporite	Middleton Dale Anhydrite Fm.	359.20	LITHOLOGY = Anhydrite with beds of mudstone and dolostone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MIDA">MIDA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of the Courceyan. DASHED

Burrowed and bioturbated intervals.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SSH">SSH</a> ].

	Claystone	Monks Park Shale Fm.	495.40	LITHOLOGY = Shaly mudstones in lower part. Black mudstones in upper part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MPSH">MPSH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 15% up in Stage 9 in the Furongian.

	Sandy claystone	Mancetter Shale Fm.	507.90	LITHOLOGY = Micaceous and pyritic mudstone with ripple-bedded sandy wisps and beds of glauconitic sandstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MCSH">MCSH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Stage 5 in Series 3 of the Cambrian. 
	Claystone	Abbey Shale Fm.	510.00	LITHOLOGY = Dark grey mudstones with thin beds of limestone and glauconitic sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASH">ASH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Stage 5 in Series 2 of the Cambrian.

Marros Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Siliceous mudstones and cherts (Aberkenfig Fm.); grey, commonly fossiliferous mudstones (Bishopston Fm.); quartzitic sandstones and conglomerates (Twrch Sandstone Fm.), occupying the basal half of the Gp. on the northeastern crops and eastern crops of the South Wales Coalfield, and quartzitic sandstones (Telpyn Point Sandstone Fm.) occupying the highest part of the Gp. locally. Pembroke Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].

Right column (region S8)	facies	100	234/201/201		off	Waters, C.N. et al (16 authors), 2007.  Stratigraphical Chart of the United Kingdom: 2 sheets -- Northern Britain & Southern Britain. British Geological Survey, 2 posters.
British Coastal Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Near-shore marine, coastal and estuarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COAS">COAS</a> ].

	TOP		195.36	CALIBRATION = Drawn 35% up in the Sinemurian
Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].  
	Clayey limestone	Blue Lias Fm.	200.41	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded limestone and calcareous mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BLI">BLI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 80% up in the Rhaetian
Penarth Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey to black mudstones with subordinate limestones and sandstones; predominantly marine in origin.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PNG">PNG</a> ].  
	Clayey limestone	Lilstock Fm.	201.01	LITHOLOGY = Includes Cotham Member (shales and siltstones) and Langport Member (porcellanous limestone below, calcareous mudstone above).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LTK">LTK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Top half of Fm.

Pembroke Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  
	Limestone	Black Rock Limestone Subgroup	349.06	LITHOLOGY = Skeletal [mainly crinoid] packstones with subordinate thin beds of shaly packstone and mudstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRL">BRL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 90% up in the Courceyan
Avon Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey mudstones and skeletal packstones. Mid to inner shelf/ramp deposits with coeval barrier, back barrier and coastal plain sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AVO">AVO</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl	Cwmyniscoy Mudstone Fm.	351.31	LITHOLOGY = Grey mudstones and skeletal packstones deposited in a mid-shelf environment.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CCM">CCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 70% up in the Courceyan Drawn 
	Oolitic limestone	Castell Coch Limestone Fm.	356.38	LITHOLOGY = Oolitic and skeletal grainstones deposited as part of a barrier complex.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CCL">CCL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Drawn 25% up in the Courceyan

Southern England	:	South-west England  (region S10)	Bristol and Gloucester  (region S11)	Hampshire Basin  (region S12)	London and Thames Valley  (region S13)	Eastern England  (region S14)	Weald Region  (region S15)		Waters, C.N. et al (16 authors), 2007. Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain and the Isle of Man, including alluvium, river terrace deposits, peat, head, cover sand and blown sand. Subdivided into subgroups defined geographically by drainage systems.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  
	TOP		0.00	CALIBRATION = Present.
	Sandstone		0.01	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Holocene
Caledonia Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of glacial, glaciofluvial, glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI">CALI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.13	LITHOLOGY = A suite of glacial, glaciofluvial, glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI">CALI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Late Pleistocene

Subdivided into subgroups defined geographically by drainage systems.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].

Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl and marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Siliceous chalk	Seaford Chalk Fm.	87.08	LITHOLOGY = Firm white chalk with conspicuous semi-continuous nodular and tabular flint seams  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SECK">SECK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 55% up in Coniacian.

	Chalk	New Pit Chalk Fm.	92.71	LITHOLOGY = Blocky, white firm chalk with numerous marls  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NPCH">NPCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 17% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	Holywell Nodular Chalk Fm.	94.88	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks with thin flaser marls and significant shell debris  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HCK">HCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 78% up in Cenomanian.
	Sandy limestone	Beer Head Limestone Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Coarse calcareous sandstone, bioclastic limestone, calcarenite and shell-detrital limestone, with a distinct nodularity and well-developed hardgrounds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BRHD">BRHD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Cenomanian.

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Holsworthy Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mudstones with abundant thin- to thick-bedded sandstones, subordinate siltstones and a few conglomerate beds. Mudstones and subordinate thin- to medium-bedded sandstones dominate the lower part and medium- to thick-bedded sandstones with subordinate mudstones and siltstones dominate the upper part. Scattered slumped units occur in the upper part.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HOWY">HOWY</a> ].

Teign Valley Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly comprises black commonly pyritic mudstones, siliceous mudstones, bedded cherts and some thin limestones. Fm.s dominated by limestone or sandstone turbidites are locally developed. Shallower water Fm.s comprising greenish mudstones with thin limestones and black mudstones with quartzitic sandstones are confined to north Cornwall. Scattered Fm.s and units of basaltic tuff and lava locally are present on the south crop of the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TEVY">TEVY</a> ].  
	Claystone	Dowhills Mudstone Fm.	323.72	LITHOLOGY = Pyritous mudstones with scattered thin siltstone and sandstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DHLS">DHLS</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in Pendleian.
	Chert	Teign Chert Fm.	325.46	LITHOLOGY = Chert, mudstone, and limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TCH">TCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Pendleian.
	Claystone	Trambley Cove Fm.	327.13	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with thin siltstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TCF">TCF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 86% up in Brigantian.
	Volcanic Ash	Tintagel Volcanic Fm.	335.43	LITHOLOGY = Basaltic calcareous tuffs with subordinate agglomerates and recrystallised carbonate-rich basaltic lavas.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TVF">TVF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in Asbian.
	Sandy claystone	Barras Nose Fm.	346.43	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones, siltstone and sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BNF">BNF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Chadian. Dashed.
Faulted	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  
	TOP		359.20	CALIBRATION = Base of Courceyan. Dashed.
Tamar Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mudstones with variable amounts of very subordinate thin siltstone, sandstone and limestone beds. Component mudstone Fm.s are characterised either by grey, purple and red, or green and grey green colourations. The mudstone Fm.s locally contain scattered units of thin- to thick-bedded limestone or sandstone. Intertonguing with the grey mudstones are thick, geographically separated Fm.s of thick-bedded to massive shallow water bioclastic and reef limestone, locally capped by condensed nodular limestones and mudstones. Thick units of basaltic lava (spilite), massive and bedded hyaloclastite, and bedded tuff are also present in the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TAMA">TAMA</a> ].  
	Claystone	Burraton Fm.	365.32	LITHOLOGY = Slaty mudstone with siltstone laminae.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BTN">BTN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Famennian. Dashed.
	Sandy claystone	Tavy Fm.	383.14	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with minor thin fine-grained sandstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TVY">TVY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Frasnian. Dashed.
	Limestone	Torquay Limestone Fm.	402.73	LITHOLOGY = No details.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TQL">TQL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in Emsian.
Meadfoot Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dark shales and siltstones with sporadic grey-brown sandstones and beds of decalcified shell debris. Upper part exhibits red coloration in places.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MDT">MDT</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Staddon Fm.	405.10	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, with thin interbedded mudstone and siltstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STG">STG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Emsian.
	Sandy claystone	Bovisand Fm.	409.31	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with thin sandstone beds and sporadic thin limestone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOV">BOV</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in Pragian.
Dartmouth Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dartmouth Gp. is divided into the Whitsand Bay Fm. and the Bin Down Fm.. The Whitsand Bay Fm. comprises reddish purple mudstone and silty mudstone, green silty mudstone to muddy siltstone (with bedding units of between 5 to 10m thick), green to mauve siltstone (in massive beds up to 6m thick that are predominantly structureless but have local lenses and laminae), grey-green with some purple sandstone (beds up to 0.8m thick with local conglomerate above erosional bases) and off-white to pale green quartzite (isolated beds up to 0.5m thick, with some grading and low-angle cross lamination). The Bin Down Fm. includes grey to dark grey cleaved mudstone, grey siltstone (laminated in place) and pale grey quartzitic sandstone. Interbedded with these sedimentary rocks are basaltic lavas and volcaniclastic beds including tuff and hyaloclastite.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRTM">DRTM</a> ].  
	Claystone		410.99	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRTM">DRTM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 5% up in Pragian.
 	Primary

Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain and the Isle of Man, including alluvium, river terrace deposits, peat, head, cover sand and blown sand. Subdivided into subgroups defined geographically by drainage systems.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].

Caledonia Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of glacial, glaciofluvial, glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CALI">CALI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.13	LITHOLOGY = A suite of glacial, glaciofluvial, glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay. Albion Glacigenic Gp. British Coastal Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of near-shore marine, coastal and estuarine deposits of sand, gravel, silt, clay and peat that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain and the Isle of Man. Includes glacio-isostatically uplifted [raised] deposits lying to the north of a hinge-line crossing northern England between the Ribble and Tyne, and isostatically uplifted Interglacial shoreline deposits around the coast of southern Britain.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COAS">COAS</a> ].

Lias Gp. 	Sandy claystone	Tavy Fm.	383.14	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with minor thin fine-grained sandstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TVY">TVY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Frasnian. Dashed.
	Limestone	Torquay Limestone Fm.	402.73	LITHOLOGY = No details.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TQL">TQL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in Emsian.
Meadfoot Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dark shales and siltstones with sporadic grey-brown sandstones and beds of decalcified shell debris. Upper part exhibits red coloration in places.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=MDT">MDT</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Staddon Fm.	405.10	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, with thin interbedded mudstone and siltstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=STG">STG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Emsian.
	Sandy claystone	Bovisand Fm.	409.31	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with thin sandstone beds and sporadic thin limestone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BOV">BOV</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 45% up in Pragian.
Dartmouth Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dartmouth Gp. is divided into the Whitsand Bay Fm. and the Bin Down Fm.. The Whitsand Bay Fm. comprises reddish purple mudstone and silty mudstone, green silty mudstone to muddy siltstone (with bedding units of between 5 to 10m thick), green to mauve siltstone (in massive beds up to 6m thick that are predominantly structureless but have local lenses and laminae), grey-green with some purple sandstone (beds up to 0.8m thick with local conglomerate above erosional bases) and off-white to pale green quartzite (isolated beds up to 0.5m thick, with some grading and low-angle cross lamination). The Bin Down Fm. includes grey to dark grey cleaved mudstone, grey siltstone (laminated in place) and pale grey quartzitic sandstone. Interbedded with these sedimentary rocks are basaltic lavas and volcaniclastic beds including tuff and hyaloclastite.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRTM">DRTM</a> ].  
	Claystone		410.99	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DRTM">DRTM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 5% up in Pragian.
 	Primary

Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain and the Isle of Man, including alluvium, river terrace deposits, peat, head, cover sand and blown sand. Subdivided into subgroups defined geographically by drainage systems.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  
	TOP		0.00	CALIBRATION = Present.

Albion Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of glacial, glaciofluvial, glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern, central and eastern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI">ALBI</a> ].

Ancholme Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.). Marros Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fissile dark grey siliceous mudstones and cherts (Aberkenfig Fm.); grey, commonly fossiliferous mudstones (Bishopston Fm.); quartzitic sandstones and conglomerates (Twrch Sandstone Fm.), occupying the basal half of the Gp. on the northeastern crops and eastern crops of the South Wales Coalfield, and quartzitic sandstones (Telpyn Point Sandstone Fm.) occupying the highest part of the Gp. locally. Marros Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fissile dark grey siliceous mudstones and cherts (Aberkenfig Fm.); grey, commonly fossiliferous mudstones (Bishopston Fm.); quartzitic sandstones and conglomerates (Twrch Sandstone Fm.), occupying the basal half of the Gp. on the northeastern crops and eastern crops of the South Wales Coalfield, and quartzitic sandstones (Telpyn Point Sandstone Fm.) occupying the highest part of the Gp. locally. Pembroke Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  
	Limestone	Oxwich Head Limestone Fm.	335.64	LITHOLOGY = Packstones and ooidal limestones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=OHL">OHL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 5% up in Asbian.

Avon Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstones and thin- to medium-bedded skeletal packstones with one to several thick units of ooidal and skeletal grainstones. Thin units of calcite mudstone and mudstone locally present. Sparse thin ironstones. Represents mid to inner shelf/ramp deposits with coeval barrier, back barrier and coastal plain sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AVO">AVO</a> ].

Right (region S11)	facies	100	234/201/201		off	Waters, C.N. et al (16 authors), 2007.  Stratigraphical Chart of the United Kingdom: 2 sheets -- Northern Britain & Southern Britain. British Geological Survey, 2 posters.
British Coastal Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of near-shore marine, coastal and estuarine deposits of sand, gravel, silt, clay and peat that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain and the Isle of Man. Includes glacio-isostatically uplifted [raised] deposits lying to the north of a hinge-line crossing northern England between the Ribble and Tyne, and isostatically uplifted Interglacial shoreline deposits around the coast of southern Britain.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COAS">COAS</a> ].

Ancholme Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.). Pembroke Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].

Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].

CALIBRATION = 40% up in Middle Pleistocene
Albion Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI">ALBI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.78	LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay. 	Soil		16.42	LITHOLOGY = Residual deposit of orange-brown and red-brown sandy clay with abundant rounded pebbles of flint formed from the dissolution of the Chalk Gp. and Palaeogene Fm.s. Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl amd marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base. Purbeck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones, limestones and evaporites of marginal freshwater, brackish and marine origin; detrital quartz occurs in parts. The Gp. (Purbeck Beds), was traditionally divided into Lower, Middle and Upper units ('beds') with a key marker, the Cinder Bed placed within the middle part of the Middle Purbeck Beds. At the type site in Dorset, the Gp. is now formally divided into the Lulworth Fm., below and the Durlston Fm. above with the base of the Durlston Fm. placed at the base of the Cinder Bed. This formal terminology can now be applied throughout the outcrop and subcrop of the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PB">PB</a> ].  
	Continental marl		147.61	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones, limestones and evaporites of marginal freshwater, brackish and marine origin.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PB">PB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Tithonian
Portland Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Upper part predominantly limestone (micrites, wackestones, packstones and grainstones) including good freestones; lower part predominantly argillaceous, dolomitic sandstones/sands; some mudstones/shales, and thin beds or nodular layers of micrite.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PL">PL</a> ].  
	Sandy limestone		149.77	LITHOLOGY = Upper limestone; Lower clayey dolomitic sandstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PL">PL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Tithonian
Ancholme Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AMG">AMG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	155.65	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous or kerogen-rich or silty or sandy); thin siltstone and cementstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Kimmeridgian.

Pembroke Limestone Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  
	Limestone		339.63	LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Holkerian. Dashed

	TOP		353.57	CALIBRATION = About middle of Courceyan
Avon Gp.	Primary 			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstones and thin- to medium-bedded skeletal packstones with one to several thick units of ooidal and skeletal grainstones. Thin units of calcite mudstone and mudstone locally present. Sparse thin ironstones. Represents mid to inner shelf/ramp deposits with coeval barrier, back barrier and coastal plain sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AVO">AVO</a> ].

British Coastal Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Near-shore marine, coastal and estuarine deposits of sand, gravel, silt, clay and peat that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=COAS">COAS</a> ].  
	TOP		0.00	CALIBRATION = Present
	Coarse-grained sandstone		0.78	LITHOLOGY = Near-shore marine, coastal and estuarine deposits of sand, gravel, silt, clay and peat that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of middle Pleistocene
Dunwich Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial gravels with subsidiary sands, clays and silts. The Gp. comprises the interpreted fluvial terrace sequences of those rivers that were either destroyed by or, in the case of the Proto-Thames, significantly modified by, the overriding ice sheets that deposited the Albion Glacigenic Gp.. The pebble contents of these various gravels can be used to demonstrate the denudation history of the source areas of the sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DUNW">DUNW</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Colchester Fm.	1.22	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CCHR">CCHR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in Dunwich Gp.
	Clayey sandstone	Sudbury Fm.	1.66	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SBRY">SBRY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 14% up in Early Pleistocene
 	Primary
	TOP		1.99	CALIBRATION = 76% up in Gelasian
Crag Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of shallow-water marine and estuarine sands, gravels, silts and clays deposited on the southwest flank of the North Sea Basin. The sands are characteristically dark green from glauconite but weather bright orange with haematite 'iron pans'. The gravels in the lower part of the Gp. are almost entirely composed of flint. Those higher in the Gp. include up to 10% of quartzite from the Midlands, igneous rocks from Wales, and chert from the Upper Greensand of southeastern England.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAG">CRAG</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone	Norwich Crag Fm.	2.25	LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained micaceous, glauconitic, locally shelly sands, with localized beds of laminated silty clays (Chillesford Clay and Easton Bavents Clay members) and rounded flint gravels (Westleton Beds).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NCG">NCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 43% up in Gelasian
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Red Crag Fm.	2.59	LITHOLOGY = Coarse-grained, poorly sorted, abundantly shelly sands.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RCG">RCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Galesian. Dashed.

Albion Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   ALBIALBI

Dunwich Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial gravels with subsidiary sands, clays and silts. The Gp. comprises the interpreted fluvial terrace sequences of those rivers that were either destroyed by or, in the case of the Proto-Thames, significantly modified by, the overriding ice sheets that deposited the Albion Glacigenic Gp.. The pebble contents of these various gravels can be used to demonstrate the denudation history of the source areas of the sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DUNW">DUNW</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Bytham Fm.	1.52	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BYTH">BYTH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 28% up in Early Pleistocene
	Clayey sandstone	Cromer Forest-bed Fm.	1.81	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRF">CRF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Early Pleistocene
Crag Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of shallow-water marine and estuarine sands, gravels, silts and clays deposited on the southwest flank of the North Sea Basin. The sands are characteristically dark green from glauconite but weather bright orange with haematite 'iron pans'. The gravels in the lower part of the Gp. are almost entirely composed of flint. Those higher in the Gp. include up to 10% of quartzite from the Midlands, igneous rocks from Wales, and chert from the Upper Greensand of southeastern England.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAG">CRAG</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Wroxham Crag Fm.	1.89	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded gravels, sands, silts and clays.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WRCG">WRCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 89% up in Gelasian
	Fine-grained sandstone	Norwich Crag Fm.	1.99	LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained micaceous, glauconitic, locally shelly sands, with localized beds of laminated silty clays (Chillesford Clay and Easton Bavents Clay members) and rounded flint gravels (Westleton Beds).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NCG">NCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 77% up in Gelasian

Carboniferous Limestone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dominated by typically bioclastic to micritic, bioturbated with common shelly, crinoidal and algal beds of limestone and coral biostromes which are darker grey, and commonly dolomitised in the lower part. The upper part is dominated by paler grey, thinner-bedded limestones with common palaeokarst surfaces, overlain by clay wayboards, which are possible weathered bentonites. Sandstone is locally common, particularly in the upper part of the Supergroup.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CL">CL</a> ].

Albion Glacigenic Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern England, Scotland and Wales, and offshore, including diamictons [till], sand, gravel, silt and clay.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI">ALBI</a> ].  
	Glacial till		0.78	LITHOLOGY = Glacial to glaciomarine deposits.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ALBI">ALBI</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Middle Pleistocene
Dunwich Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial gravels with subsidiary sands, clays and silts. The Gp. comprises the interpreted fluvial terrace sequences of those rivers that were either destroyed by or, in the case of the Proto-Thames, significantly modified by, the overriding ice sheets that deposited the Albion Glacigenic Gp.. The pebble contents of these various gravels can be used to demonstrate the denudation history of the source areas of the sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DUNW">DUNW</a> ].  
	Clayey sandstone	Bytham Fm.	1.52	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BYTH">BYTH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 28% up in Early Pleistocene
	Clayey sandstone	Cromer Forest-bed Fm.	1.81	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRF">CRF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Early Pleistocene
Crag Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = A suite of shallow-water marine and estuarine sands, gravels, silts and clays deposited on the southwest flank of the North Sea Basin. The sands are characteristically dark green from glauconite but weather bright orange with haematite 'iron pans'. The gravels in the lower part of the Gp. are almost entirely composed of flint. Those higher in the Gp. include up to 10% of quartzite from the Midlands, igneous rocks from Wales, and chert from the Upper Greensand of southeastern England.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CRAG">CRAG</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Wroxham Crag Fm.	1.89	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded gravels, sands, silts and clays.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WRCG">WRCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 89% up in Gelasian
	Fine-grained sandstone	Norwich Crag Fm.	1.99	LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained micaceous, glauconitic, locally shelly sands, with localized beds of laminated silty clays (Chillesford Clay and Easton Bavents Clay members) and rounded flint gravels (Westleton Beds).  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NCG">NCG</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 77% up in Gelasian
	Gap		2.20	CALIBRATION = 50% up in Gelasian
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Red Crag Fm.	2.59	LITHOLOGY = Coarse-grained, poorly sorted, abundantly shelly sands.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Gelasian. Dashed.
	Gap		3.20	CALIBRATION = 40% up in Placenzian.
	Sandy limestone	Coralline Crag Fm.	4.99	LITHOLOGY = Carbonate-rich skeletal sands.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Zanclean.
 	Primary
	TOP		50.11	CALIBRATION = 79% up in Ypresian.
Thames Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Silty clay/mudstone, sandy silts and sandy clayey silts of marine origin.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=THAM">THAM</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	London Clay Fm.	52.99	LITHOLOGY = Fine, sandy, silty clay/silty clay. Glauconitic at base.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LC">LC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 39% up in Ypresian.
	Sandy claystone	Harwich Fm.	55.08	LITHOLOGY = Glauconitic sandy clays and very fine-grained glauconitic sands; marine fauna, locally brackish.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HWH">HWH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in Ypresian.

	Gap		65.50	CALIBRATION = Base of Danian. Dashed.
Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl amd marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Chalk	"Trimingham Chalk"	72.54	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TRCK">TRCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 85% up in Campanian. Dashed.
	Chalk	"Norwich Chalk"	78.49	LITHOLOGY = Not found in BGS website  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  CALIBRATION = 39% up in Campanian.
	Chalk	Portsdown Fm.	80.69	LITHOLOGY = Chalk with marl seams (particularly in the lower part) and flint bands, although less flinty than the Culver Chalk Fm..  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PCK">PCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 22% up in Campanian.
	Siliceous chalk	Culver Chalk Fm.	82.37	LITHOLOGY = Chalk, with flint seams. Flints are generally large and in the upper part tabular.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CUCK">CUCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 9% up in Campanian.
	Siliceous chalk	Newhaven Chalk Fm.	85.85	LITHOLOGY = Smooth white chalks with numerous marl seams and flint bands, including abundant Zoophycos flints near base  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NCK">NCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Santonian.
	Siliceous chalk	Seaford Chalk Fm.	87.22	LITHOLOGY = Firm white chalk with conspicuous semi-continuous nodular and tabular flint seams  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SECK">SECK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 50% up in Conlacian.
	Chalk	Lewes Nodular Chalk Formaion	88.58	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks and hardgrounds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LECH">LECH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Conlacian.
	Chalk	New Pit Chalk Fm.	93.00	LITHOLOGY = Blocky, white firm chalk with numerous marls  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NPCH">NPCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 11% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	Holywell Nodular Chalk Fm.	93.97	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks with thin flaser marls and significant shell debris  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HCK">HCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 93% up in Cenomanian.
	Chalk	Zig Zag Chalk Fm.	94.88	LITHOLOGY = Blocky chalk, lower part has rhythmic alternations of marls and chalk  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ZZCH">ZZCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 78% up in Cenomanian.
	Shallow-marine marl	West Melbury Marly Chalk Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Couplets of soft, marly chalk and hard grey limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WMCH">WMCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Cenomanian.

Ancholme Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, marine mudstone and silty mudstone; beds of argillaceous limestone nodules (or more or less persistent beds) at some levels; units of siltstone and sandstone at some levels, widespread near base (in Kellaways Fm.), in middle part (West Walton Fm.) and more locally at other levels (notably Kimmeridge Clay Fm. of Oxon/Buckinghamshire); shelly marl, limestone and sandy limestone developed locally (notably in the West Walton Fm.).   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AMG">AMG</a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	156.26	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous or kerogen-rich or silty or sandy); thin siltstone and cementstone beds.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 89% up in Oxfordian.
	Shallow-marine marl	Ampthill Clay Fm.	157.98	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone, mainly smooth or slightly silty, pale to medium grey with argillaceous limestone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AMC">AMC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 58% up in Oxfordian.
	Shallow-marine marl	West Walton Fm.	159.65	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous mudstone, silty mudstone and siltstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WWB">WWB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 28% up in Oxfordian.
	Claystone	Oxford Clay Fm.	162.62	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with sporadic beds of clayey limestone nodules.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=OXC">OXC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Callovian.
	Sandy claystone	Kellaways Fm.	163.68	LITHOLOGY = Silty mudstone, with beds of calcareous siltstone and sandstone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KLB">KLB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Callovian.

	Claystone	Rutland Fm.	168.11	LITHOLOGY = Marine mudstone passing up into non-marine mudstone and siltstone, with a greenish-grey rootlet bed at the top and basal sandstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RLD">RLD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 89% up in Bajocian.

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Marginal limestone facies also occur.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LI">LI</a> ].

Carboniferous Limestone Supergroup	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Dominated by typically bioclastic to micritic, bioturbated with common shelly, crinoidal and algal beds of limestone and coral biostromes which are darker grey, and commonly dolomitised in the lower part. The upper part is dominated by paler grey, thinner-bedded limestones with common palaeokarst surfaces, overlain by clay wayboards, which are possible weathered bentonites. Sandstone is locally common, particularly in the upper part of the Supergroup.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CL">CL</a> ].  
	Limestone		359.20	LITHOLOGY = bioclastic to micritic, bioturbated with common shelly, crinoidal and algal beds of limestone and coral biostromes  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CL">CL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Courceyan. Dashed.

Britannia Catchments Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  
	TOP		0.00	CALIBRATION = Present
	Conglomerate		0.72	LITHOLOGY = Fluvial, lacustrine, mass movement, periglacial and aeolian deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout Great Britain  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=BCAT">BCAT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in Middle Pleistocene.
Residual Deposits Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Deposits formed by weathering and solifluction of original Cenozoic bedrock.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RESID">RESID</a> ].  
	Soil	Clay-with-Flints	16.73	LITHOLOGY = Residual deposit of orange-brown and red-brown sandy clay with abundant rounded pebbles of flint formed from the dissolution of the Chalk Gp. and Palaeogene Fm.s.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CWF">CWF</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 83% up in Burdigalian. Dashed. Shares same range with Residual Deposits Gp. to the exact left.

	TOP		85.03	CALIBRATION = 90% up in Santonian. Dashed.
Chalk Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly chalk, some nodular or forming cemented layers, with marl seams in parts, beds of flint nodules or flint layers in the upper parts, and beds of limestone, chalky marl amd marly chalk in the lower part with glauconitic marl or sand at base.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Siliceous chalk	Newhaven Chalk Fm.	84.92	LITHOLOGY = Smooth white chalks with numerous marl seams and flint bands, including abundant Zoophycos flints near base  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NCK">NCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in Santonian.
	Siliceous chalk	Seaford Chalk Fm.	86.40	LITHOLOGY = Firm white chalk with conspicuous semi-continuous nodular and tabular flint seams  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SECK">SECK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 75% up in Conaician
	Chalk	Lewes Nodular Chalk Fm.	89.57	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks and hardgrounds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LECH">LECH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	New Pit Chalk Fm.	91.56	LITHOLOGY = Blocky, white firm chalk with numerous marls  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NPCH">NPCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	Holywell Nodular Chalk Fm.	93.67	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks with thin flaser marls and significant shell debris  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HCK">HCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 98% up in Cenomanian.
	Chalk	Zig Zag Chalk Fm.	95.97	LITHOLOGY = Blocky chalk, lower part has rhythmic alternations of marls and chalk  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ZZCH">ZZCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Cenomanian.
	Shallow-marine marl	West Melbury Marly Chalk Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Couplets of soft, marly chalk and hard grey limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WMCH">WMCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Cenomanian.

Purbeck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones, limestones and evaporites of marginal freshwater, brackish and marine origin; detrital quartz occurs in parts. The Gp. (Purbeck Beds), was traditionally divided into Lower, Middle and Upper units ('beds') with a key marker, the Cinder Bed placed within the middle part of the Middle Purbeck Beds. At the type site in Dorset, the Gp. is now formally divided into the Lulworth Fm., below and the Durlston Fm. above with the base of the Durlston Fm. placed at the base of the Cinder Bed. This formal terminology can now be applied throughout the outcrop and subcrop of the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PB">PB</a> ].  
	Continental marl	Durlston Fm.	144.40	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded, shelly limestones and dark mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DURN">DURN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Berriasian.
	Clayey limestone	Lulworth Fm.	146.00	LITHOLOGY = Lower ostracod-rich calcarenites; Upper interbedded grey mudstones and white micrites.  Contains anhydrite and gypsum  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LULW">LULW</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in Tithonian.

[For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PL">PL</a> ].

Lias Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Predominantly grey, well bedded, marine calcareous mudstone and silty mudstone; thin tabular or nodular beds of argillaceous limestone, particularly in the lower part; thicker units of siltstone and sandstone, particularly in the upper part, and ironstone, particularly in the middle part. Pembroke Lst	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].

British Coastal Deposits Gp. British Coastal Deposits Gp. 	Soil	Lenham Fm.	13.82	LITHOLOGY = Ferruginous sands, brightly coloured, fine-grained, micaceous and glauconitic. Beds of small, black, well-rounded, flint pebbles near base. [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CK">CK</a> ].  
	Chalk	Lewes Nodular Chalk Fm.	89.57	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks and hardgrounds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LECH">LECH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	New Pit Chalk Fm.	91.56	LITHOLOGY = Blocky, white firm chalk with numerous marls  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=NPCH">NPCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in Turonian.
	Chalk	Holywell Nodular Chalk Fm.	93.67	LITHOLOGY = Hard nodular chalks with thin flaser marls and significant shell debris  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HCK">HCK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 98% up in Cenomanian.
	Chalk	Zig Zag Chalk Fm.	95.97	LITHOLOGY = Blocky chalk, lower part has rhythmic alternations of marls and chalk  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ZZCH">ZZCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Cenomanian.
	Shallow-marine marl	West Melbury Marly Chalk Fm.	99.60	LITHOLOGY = Couplets of soft, marly chalk and hard grey limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WMCH">WMCH</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Cenomanian.
Selborne Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SELB">SELB</a> ].  
	Claystone	Gault Fm.	109.89	LITHOLOGY = Grey clay or mudstone, glauconitic in part, with a sandy base  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=GLT">GLT</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 17% up in Albian.
Lower Greensand Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Mainly sands and sandstones (varying from well-sorted fine-grained to poorly sorted medium- to coarse-grained) with silts and clays in some intervals.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LGS">LGS</a> ].  
	Coarse-grained sandstone	Folkestone Fm.	112.65	LITHOLOGY = Medium- and coarse-grained, well-sorted sandstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FO">FO</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 95% up in Aptian.
	Clayey sandstone	Sandgate Fm.	114.34	LITHOLOGY = Fine sands, silts and silty clays, commonly glauconitic.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SAB">SAB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 82% up in Aptian.
	Sandstone	Hythe Fm.	117.85	LITHOLOGY = Fine- to medium-grained, sparsely glauconitic sands, sandstones and silts.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=HY">HY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 55% up in Aptian.
	Claystone	Atherfield Clay Fm.	122.40	LITHOLOGY = Clays to clayey silts  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AC">AC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Aptian.
Wealden Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstones, siltstones, shales, limestones and clay ironstones of predominantly non-marine facies.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=W">W</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	Weald Clay Fm.	133.87	LITHOLOGY = Silty clay , with silts, sands, ironstones and clay ironstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WC">WC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Hauterivian.
	Fine-grained sandstone	Tunbridge Wells Sand Fm.	137.03	LITHOLOGY = Lower unit of thinly interbedded fine-grained sandstones.  Upper unit of massive and thickly bedded, fine- and medium-grained sandstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LTW">LTW</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 55% up Valanginian.
	Claystone	Wadhurst Clay Fm.	139.11	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones and silty mudstones.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WDC">WDC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 17% up Valanginian.
	Fine-grained sandstone	Ashdown Fm.	141.24	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=ASD">ASD</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Berriasian.
Purbeck Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones, limestones and evaporites of marginal freshwater, brackish and marine origin; detrital quartz occurs in parts. The Gp. (Purbeck Beds), was traditionally divided into Lower, Middle and Upper units ('beds') with a key marker, the Cinder Bed placed within the middle part of the Middle Purbeck Beds. At the type site in Dorset, the Gp. is now formally divided into the Lulworth Fm., below and the Durlston Fm. above with the base of the Durlston Fm. placed at the base of the Cinder Bed. This formal terminology can now be applied throughout the outcrop and subcrop of the Gp..   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PB">PB</a> ].  
	Continental marl	Durlston Fm.	144.40	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded, shelly limestones and dark mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=DURN">DURN</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Berriasian.
	Clayey limestone	Lulworth Fm.	146.00	LITHOLOGY = Lower ostracod-rich calcarenites; Upper interbedded grey mudstones and white micrites.  Contains anhydrite and gypsum  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LULW">LULW</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 90% up in Tithonian.
Portland Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Upper part predominantly limestone (micrites, wackestones, packstones and grainstones) including good freestones; lower part predominantly argillaceous, dolomitic sandstones/sands; some mudstones/shales, and thin beds or nodular layers of micrite.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PL">PL</a> ].  
	Limestone	Portland Limestone Fm.	147.61	LITHOLOGY = Limestone (micrites, wackestones, packstones and grainstones) including good freestones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PLND">PLND</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Tithonian.
	Clayey sandstone	Portland Sand Fm.	149.23	LITHOLOGY = Argillaceous, dolomitic sandstones/sands  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=POSA">POSA</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Tithonian.
 	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  
	Claystone	Kimmeridge Clay Fm.	155.65	LITHOLOGY = Mudstones (calcareous, kerogen-rich, or silty); thin siltstone and cementstone beds  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KC">KC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Group name not on chart.
Corallian Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Complex succession of interdigitating limestones, marls, sandstones, sands, siltstones, silts, spiculites, mudstones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CR">CR</a> ].  
	Clayey limestone		159.54	LITHOLOGY = Limestones, marls, sandstones, and mudstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CR">CR</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 30% up in Oxfordian.
 	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Not found.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub="></a> ].  
	Claystone	Oxford Clay Fm.	162.27	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with limestone nodules  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=OXC">OXC</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 70% up in Callovian.
	Claystone	Kellaways Fm.	164.03	LITHOLOGY = Silty mudstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=KLB">KLB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Callovian.
Great Oolite Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Calcareous (rarely oolitic, despite the name!) and argillaceous Fm.s  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=GOG">GOG</a> ].  
	Limestone	Cornbrash Fm.	164.16	LITHOLOGY = Bioclastic wackestone and packstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=CB">CB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 20% up in Great Oolite Gp.
	Shallow-marine marl	Forest Marble Fm.	164.19	LITHOLOGY = Mudstone with lenticular beds of limestone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FMB">FMB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 40% up in Great Oolite Gp.
	Oolitic limestone	Athelstan Oolite Fm.	164.30	LITHOLOGY = No details given.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AOL">AOL</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 60% up in Great Oolite Gp.
	Oolitic limestone	Taynton Lst Fm.	164.70	LITHOLOGY = Bioclastic ooidal grainstone.  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=TY">TY</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Great Oolite Gp.
	Shallow-marine marl	Fuller' s Earth Fm.	167.39	LITHOLOGY = Calcareous silty mudstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=FE">FE</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 10% up in Bathonian.
Inferior Oolite Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Varied sucession of ooidal, peloidal, marly, sandy, ferruginous and shelly limestones, with subordinate sandstone, calcareous mudstone and mudstone beds.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=INO">INO</a> ].

	TOP		306.80	CALIBRATION = 5% up in Stephanian.
Warwickshire Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone and mudstone, some grey strata, coals not common, local conglomerates, localised beds of Spirorbis limestone.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK">WAWK</a> ].  
	Fine-grained sandstone		307.54	LITHOLOGY = Sandstone, siltstone and mudstone  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=WAWK">WAWK</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 80% up in Moscovian.

	Gap		309.36	CALIBRATION = 45% up in Moscovian.
South Wales Coal Measures Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Grey (productive) coal-bearing mudstones/siltstones with seatearths and minor sandstones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SWCM">SWCM</a> ].  
	Sandy claystone	South Wales Upper Coal Measures Fm.	310.92	LITHOLOGY = Coal-bearing mudstones/siltstones, with seatearths and minor sandstones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SWUCM">SWUCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 2/3rds up in South Wales Coal Measures Gp..

	Sandy claystone	South Wales Lower Coal Measures Fm.	313.94	LITHOLOGY = Coal-bearing mudstones/siltstones, with seatearths and minor sandstones.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=SWLCM">SWLCM</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 65% up in Bashkirian.
 	Primary
	TOP		336.23	CALIBRATION = 90% up in Holkerian.
Pembroke Lst	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones with some calcite- and dolomite-mudstones, sandstones and mudstones, and a few coals and cherts. Waulsortian reef limestones occur in the south. Extensively dolomitised on the east crop of the South Wales Coalfield. Interfingers with fluvial sandstones in the Monmouth, Chepstow and Bristol areas. Deposited in a ramp setting that, with time, became a platform.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  
	Limestone		338.76	LITHOLOGY = Skeletal and ooidal limestones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=PEMB">PEMB</a> ].  CALIBRATION = 23% up in Holkerian.
 	Primary
	Gap		349.06	CALIBRATION = 90% up in Courceyan.
Avon Gp.	Primary			LITHOLOGY = Interbedded grey mudstones and thin- to medium-bedded skeletal packstones with one to several thick units of ooidal and skeletal grainstones. Thin units of calcite mudstone and mudstone locally present. Sparse thin ironstones. Represents mid to inner shelf/ramp deposits with coeval barrier, back barrier and coastal plain sediments.   [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AVO">AVO</a> ].  
	Shallow-marine marl		359.20	LITHOLOGY = Interbedded mudstones and skeletal packstones  [For details click <a href="http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=AVO">AVO</a> ].  CALIBRATION = Base of Courceyan. Dashed.
 	Primary
	Gap		369.60	CALIBRATION = 32% up in Famennian.
